{{cleanup|date=November 2011}} {{dablink|For the musician, see [[Dan Siegel (musician)]]. For the physician, see [[Daniel J. Siegel]]}} '''Daniel Mark Siegel''', or '''Dan Siegel''', is a civil-rights attorney at the Oakland-based law firm, [[Siegel & Yee]]. Siegel was born and raised in [[New York City]] and on [[Long Island]]. He attended high school in New York, graduating second in his class. He attended [[Hamilton College (New York)]] in 1963-1967 majoring in Philosophy and Religion; he received his B.A. degree there in 1967,{{cite web |url= http://www.siegelyee.com/dansiegel.html |title= Dan Siegel's biography |publisher= Siegel & Yee |location= [[Oakland, California]] |archiveurl= http://www.webcitation.org/63CuogxVI |archivedate= 2011-11-14 |deadurl= no |accessdate= 2011-11-14 |quote= }} graduating magna cum laude. Siegel was a student activist in 1967-1970 while he attended the [[UC Berkeley School of Law|University of California, Berkeley, School of Law]]. He was also a leader in the local [[Students for a Democratic Society (1960 organization)|Students for a Democratic Society]]. As [[UC Berkeley]] Student President-Elect in 1969, Siegel is known for his role in the student rebellion on "Bloody Thursday," when thousands of students clashed with hundreds of [[California Highway Patrol]] officers and Alameda County sheriff's deputies sent by the office of then-California governor [[Ronald Reagan]] to assert control over a piece of property known as "[[People's Park (Berkeley)|People's Park]]." During a rally on [[Sproul Plaza]] on that day, May 15, 1969, Siegel received the microphone as the crowd of 3,000 agitated to reclaim their community space, and when he yelled "Take the park!" a riot ensued that ended with authorities firing at demonstrators, killing one.Weiss, Norman. The Daily Californian. "People's Park: Then & Now." 17 March 1997.{{cite news |title= Berkeley Battling Over People's Park 30 Years After Clash |first= Michelle |last= Locke |url= http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19990419&slug=2956007 |newspaper= [[The Seattle Times]] |agency= [[Associated Press]] |date= 1999-04-19 |accessdate= 2011-11-14 |quote= But 30 years ago this spring, Siegel was a counterculture catalyst, the man whose exhortation to 'Take the park!' was the precursor to a bloody clash between University of California students and police that left one man dead, another blinded and a city locked in martial law. |archiveurl= http://www.webcitation.org/63CT0tgd1 |archivedate= 2011-11-14 |deadurl= no}} He received his [[Juris Doctor|J.D.]] degree from the University of California School of Law in 1970. He passed the California [[bar examination]], but was denied a license to practice law by a subcommittee of the [[State Bar of California]]. Siegel took his appeal to the [[California Supreme Court]], which overruled the State Bar and found that Siegel possessed the requisite "moral character" to practice law.{{cite web |url= http://law.justia.com/cases/california/cal3d/10/156.html |title= Siegel v. Committee of Bar Examiners, 10 Cal.3d 156 |author= Supreme Court of California |authorlink= Supreme Court of California |date= 1973-10-09 |publisher= Justia Inc. |location= [[Mountain View, California]] |archiveurl= http://www.webcitation.org/63CUx7ze9 |archivedate= 2011-11-14 |deadurl= no |accessdate= 2011-11-14 |quote= }} According to [[Trevor Loudon|KeyWiki]]'s article on Siegel,{{cite web |url= http://keywiki.org/index.php/Dan_Siegel |title= Dan Siegel - KeyWiki |date= 2011-07-28 |publisher= [[KeyWiki]] |archiveurl= http://www.webcitation.org/63DxYZcQa |archivedate= 2011-11-15 |deadurl= no |accessdate= 2011-11-15 |quote= In 1993 Dan Siegel was listed among 'former fellows, project co-ordinators and staff' of the Institute for Policy Studies, Washington DC.}} Siegel was a founder of the [[New American Movement]] (a Marxist organization) and is listed among "former fellows, project co-ordinators and staff" of the [[Institute for Policy Studies]]. Today, Siegel is a civil rights attorney at the Oakland-based law firm, Siegel & Yee.[http://www.siegelyee.com Siegel & Yee] In recent years, he has won a series of high-profile [[sexual harassment]] and [[employment discrimination]] lawsuits, and has represented clients such as the [[National Union of Healthcare Workers]]. He has served as both general counsel and Interim Executive Director of the [[Pacifica Radio|Pacifica Radio Foundation]], and has currently serves as a director on both the Pacifica National Board and the Local Station Board of [[KPFA|KPFA-FM]] in Berkeley. In 2006 he completed an eight-year tenure on the [[Oakland Unified School District]] Board of Directors. Siegel, a long-time friend of Oakland Mayor [[Jean Quan]], served as her legal adviser until November 14, 2011, when he resigned in protest. Siegel subsequently announced, via Twitter: "No longer Mayor Quan's legal advisor. Resigned at 2 am. Support [[Occupy Oakland]], not the 1% and its government facilitators."{{cite news |title= Occupy Oakland: demonstrators prepare for police action â live updates |first= Adam |last= Gabbatt |url= http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/blog/2011/nov/14/occupy-oakland-police-action-live?CMP=NECNETTXT8187 |newspaper= [[The Guardian]] |date= 2011-11-14 |accessdate= 2011-11-14 |quote= Quan's legal advisor, Dan Siegel, has resigned from his position in protest at the eviction. |archiveurl= |archivedate= |deadurl= }}{{cite web |url= http://twitter.com/#!/DanMSiegel/statuses/136100377203453952 |title= Siegel's tweet |date= 2011-11-14 |publisher= [[Twitter]] |archiveurl= |archivedate= |deadurl= |accessdate= 2011-11-14 |quote= No longer Mayor Quan's legal advisor. Resigned at 2 am. Support Occupy Oakland, not the 1% and its government facilitators.}} The ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' described Siegel as "one of Oakland's most active and vocal police critics".{{cite news |title= Quan's top legal adviser resigns over raid |first= Matthai |last= Kuruvila |url= http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/11/14/BAGA1LURQ7.DTL |newspaper= [[San Francisco Chronicle]] |date= 2011-11-14 |accessdate= 2011-11-14 |quote= Dan Siegel, a civil rights attorney and one of Oakland's most active and vocal police critics, said the city should have done more to work with campers before sending in police. |archiveurl= http://www.webcitation.org/63CKQnIHg |archivedate= 2011-11-14 |deadurl= no}} Siegel and his wife, Anne Butterfield Weills, have lived in Oakland since 1977. Weills is an attorney who is listed "of counsel" at Siegel & Yee.{{cite web |url= http://www.siegelyee.com/anneweills.html |title= Anne Butterfield Weills' biography |publisher= Siegel & Yee |location= [[Oakland, California]] |archiveurl= http://www.webcitation.org/63Cv6Pl8k |archivedate= 2011-11-14 |deadurl= no |accessdate= 2011-11-14 |quote= }} Weills has two sons and a grandson. Her younger son, Michael Siegel, graduated from [[Skyline High School (Oakland, California)|Skyline High School]] in 1995 and is an associate attorney with Siegel & Yee.{{cite web |url= http://www.siegelyee.com/michaelsiegel.html |title= Michael Siegel's biography |publisher= Siegel & Yee |location= [[Oakland, California]] |archiveurl= http://www.webcitation.org/63CvlEeEy |archivedate= 2011-11-14 |deadurl= no |accessdate= 2011-11-14 |quote= }} Before becoming an attorney, Michael was a teacher in the [[Oakland Unified School District]].{{cite web |url= http://bex.ousd.k12.ca.us/DanSiegel.asp |title= Dan Siegel - District 6 Board Member |year= 2006 |publisher= [[Oakland Unified School District]] |archiveurl= http://www.webcitation.org/63CbF6Tke |archivedate= 2011-11-14 |deadurl= no |accessdate= 2011-11-14 |quote= }} Anne Butterfield Weills (b. March 14, 1942) is the second child of John C.S. Weills III and Audrey Davis.{{cite web |url= http://familytreemaker.genealogy.com/users/w/a/l/Derek-Walter-/WEBSITE-0001/UHP-0039.html |title= My Genealogy - Information about Anne Butterfield Weills |publisher= [[Ancestry.com]] |accessdate= 2011-11-15}} Weills married journalist [[Robert Scheer]] in 1965; they later divorced.{{cite web |url= http://www.discoverthenetworks.org/individualProfile.asp?indid=1712 |title= Christopher Scheer - Discover the Networks |publisher= [[David Horowitz Freedom Center|DiscoverTheNetworks.org]] |archiveurl= http://www.webcitation.org/63E40AhZq |archivedate= 2011-11-15 |deadurl= no |accessdate= 2011-11-15 |quote= Son of National Lawyer Guild attorney Anne Weills}} Weills' older son is [[Christopher Scheer|Christopher Weills Scheer]] (b.
